103953.comment: I am a cyclist who cycles to/from work as well as to other destinations on a regular basis. Bike lanes are important infrastructure to increase the safety for cyclists as well as increasing the number of commuters compared to single occupancy vehicles. Prioritizing cars over public transit and cycling will be detrimental in the long run. Data from many countries have demonstrated that bike lanes do not cause congestion. In fact, cars are what cause congestion, and adding bike lanes and more public transit will lead to decreased congestion. I do not support this proposal for the province to have authority of when bike lanes can be implemented. Ontario should be focusing on how to expand transit and bike lanes instead.

103954.comment: Absolutely stupid to build Highway 413 right through the Oak Ridges Moraine and destroy the environment in the process.  And a bike path is not safe on a noisy highway.  Even if a fence is put up, it is still full of exhaust.  Please invest in bike paths, but no more highways, especially not through environmentally sensitive areas.

103955.comment: This proposal is yet another ham fisted attempt by this incompetent provincial government to intervene and impede the sustainable growth of the cities in our province. There is no factual basis that increased lanes of traffic reduce congestion - they simply encourage more cars on the road which worsens congestion in the long term. We should be striving to increase to flow of people, not cars, in our cities. Cars are a horribly inefficient way to move people in a city, whereas biking and use of public transit should be encouraged. Increased bike lanes additionally promote healthy living, benefitting everyone in the healthcare system. Constricting these locally-led changes with frivolous red tape flies in the face of conservatism and municipal jurisdiction, and calls into question the utility of a costly ministry of red tape réduction. End this nonsense NOW.

103956.comment:
Bike lanes are a proven public safety measure that reduce accidents, improve traffic flow, and promote environmental sustainability. Studies show that dedicated cycling infrastructure significantly lowers the rate of accidents involving cyclists and motor vehicles. In cities where bike lanes are properly integrated, they also ease congestion by encouraging more people to cycle rather than drive, helping to reduce overall traffic. Furthermore, bike lanes promote public health by supporting active transportation and reducing pollution.
The Ontario government's push to remove bike lanes in Toronto, framing it as a measure against gridlock, is a clear example of prioritizing culture wars over public safety. This not only disregards the well-being of urban cyclists but undermines efforts to create safer, greener cities. Public infrastructure decisions should be guided by evidence and community needs, not political maneuvering. Shame on this government for putting ideology before the safety and health of its citizens.

103959.comment: Bike lanes are essential corridors for commuters that keep people safe, supports local businesses and contribute to a vibrant, modern city. Eliminating bike lanes will not ease traffic and it will endanger lives. Another Dud Ford solution that does not solve anything, wastes taxpayer money and harms people.

103960.comment:
The provincial government should not be overstepping into municipal territory, and this is a massive waste of public resources, particularly in scenarios where labour has already been spent in implementing the new bike lanes.

If a lane needs to be saved, parking should be removed from major streets in order to create the space. 103966.comment:
This would increase not decrease car traffic, my data proves it.
I live on yonge & can see the bike lanes from my balcony. I counted the amount of bikers and cars going through in an exactly 1 hour period on 8 different occasions, at different periods throughout the day.
The 2 bike lanes averaged 70% of the traffic going by car in the two car lanes. Since the two bike lanes are the same size as one car lane the bike lanes had a 40% increase in utilization per square foot.
If we took out the bike lanes many would choose to drive & it’d likely increase traffic for cars.
Bike lanes are also the cheapest mode of transport to maintain per kilometer.
I think the best solution is to steal from Europe, force new condo developments to have Green P parking at top floors of garages so we can move street parking underground opening up extra lane ways. This would also help combat the fact many new buildings don’t have guest parking which has resulted in more street parking being filled.

103967.comment: I am a doctor that works on University Ave and I cycle from High Park using the Bloor bike lanes everyday.  I am able to do so only because of the protected bike lanes. Bike lanes protect cyclists and pedestrians from cars and it is absolutely vital that we keep this critical infrastructure.

103968.comment:
